Award.AwardTitle: SL-CN: Science of Learning in Adolescence: Integrating Developmental Studies in Animals and Humans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Science of Learning Collaborative Network brings together researchers from across the University of California-Berkeley and the University of California-San Francisco, to advance scientific understanding of developmental changes that occur in the learning processes of children and adolescents. Growing evidence shows that learning processes and the underlying brain systems go through important developmental changes. These changes begin during infancy and early childhood, but they also extend much later in pubertal maturation and adolescent development. A team-science approach will be used to address these complex issues. The collaborative research network includes expertise in the developmental science of adolescence, and in the science of learning in both human and animal models. A deeper understanding of the developmental changes in specific learning processes in adolescence will inform educational methods and interventions. With greater developmental precision, it should be possible to design more effective education for specific age groups. The long-term goals are to help transform the adolescent "window of vulnerability" (when so many youth become bored and disengaged from school) into a "window of opportunity" (a natural period of curiosity, exploration, and unique learning opportunities).

This collaborative research network builds upon (and helps to integrate) four distinct areas in the science of learning: a) the developmental science of adolescence; b) animal models of brain development in adolescence; c) animal models of learning, and d) computational modeling of learning in humans and animals. The network members will work together to develop new methods, tasks, and analyses that better isolate specific learning variables under transition at adolescence. By tracking pubertal measures as well as age, the work is expected to illuminate the role of puberty onset in developmental transitions in learning, independent from age. The use of mouse models will enable experiments that delineate the role of specific aspects (and timing) of puberty in relation to these specific changes in learning. The integration of human and animal models in parallel experiments will establish a bridge between the fields of developmental science, computational neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, and systems neurobiology. Scientists and trainees will participate in 'cross-training' opportunities through network meetings, contributing to building a stronger interdisciplinary culture of interaction and collaboration. Undergraduate trainees from underserved backgrounds will also participate in the network.

The award is from the Science of Learning-Collaborative Networks (SL-CN) Program, with funding from the SBE Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences (BCS), the SBE Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (SMA), and the CISE Division of Computer and Network Systems (CNS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
We examined how specific aspects of  learning undergo changes during adolescence in humans and mice using parallel tasks. In humans and mice, we found that learning changes with age but that the trajectory of development differs depending on the task structure and species tested. Our computational analyses of these trajectories suggest learning is supported by different systems depending on the level of uncertainty and volatility in the task and the age and pubertal status of the participant. 

 

In humans in uncertain and volatile environments we find that the youth age 13-15 can outperform adults and younger youth, with performance showing an inverted U shaped trajectory. In more stable, less volatile environments, learning improves with age and adults (20-30) show performance advantages over youth age 8-18. These changes were partially driven by a decrease in decision noise with age in years 8-18, consistently across tasks. However, it was also largely driven by changes in reward-based learning systems. Surprisingly, we found little evidence for changes in working memory contributions to learning with age, but did isolate significant changes in working memory decay and capacity at puberty onset.

 

In mice, when we tested during adolescent ages we found performance and basic measures of reinforcement learning were either already adultlike or superior to adults depending on the stask. More subtle analyses showed evidence of growth of working memory use with age. 

We speculate that inverted U shaped trajectories in performance (in humans) and early maturation of performance (in mice) during adolescence exist to support navigation of new environments during the transition to independence. 

 

In human subjects, we saw no sex differences in the development of learning. However, positive relationships observed in two tasks in human subjects support the possibility that pubertal onset and development drives some changes in learning during adolescence in humans. In mice, sex differenes were evident at all ages tested and hormonal manipulations of puberty in males and females had different effects on behavior in males and females. There is still a need to replicate and better delineate the role of pubertal processes in learning in longitudinal studies and to examine the underlying mechanisms in specific neurals systems that are associated with these findings. We anticipate that specific circuits may show differential sensitivity to hormones. Therefore we anticipate that some aspects of behavioral development will be strongly linked to pubertal maturation, while others are largely independent of puberty but still linked to development with age. 

 

Broader impacts: Our developmental data highlight the enormous changes in learning with age age 8-18. We may impact educators working with different ages with these three insights:  1) One primary insight is that choice is noisier process in younger children even when learning is accurate and successful, performance may be lower due to decision noise. 2) We recommend educators (and researchers engaged in studying learning) not only consider age, but also carefully assess the design of the information context and nature of feedback, particularly signals that indicate volatility and uncertainty in the environment. These variables are likely to alter success of different ages to a different extent due to differences in the state they evoke and the learning systems recruited to perform in the task. 3) While we did not study experience of adversity explicitly in this project, we further anticipate that life history and experience of adversity will additionally interact with task or educational environment context. 4) Our data suggest puberty onset and processes may affect some aspects of learning. While these data need to be confirmed, the data suggest the effects of earlier puberty or delayed puberty may merit further research.  

 

In our broader research network was also discussed intervention and public health investment (Dahl et al 2018) . The dream to understand basic learning could have far reaching value.  If education and health interventions could be targeted more efficiently, in the most efficient manner and/or at a more effective period of life,  this would have enormous implications for education and health on a global scale.
